text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 5.5.3, Decedent Estates and Estate Taxes, Working Decedent Cases.
) IRM

: Added new section levy of inherited IRA. (

and associated closing codes. (

Small Business/Self-Employed Collection
Table of Contents
Cases
) Purpose: This IRM section provides official policy and procedures to gate and resolve accounts involving deceased taxpayers that owe taxes. (
) Audience: The guidance in this IRM is speciﬁcally intended for revenue officers, their managers and advisors, although other employees in SB/SE in other functions may ﬁnd them useful. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, SBSE. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy, SBSE, Enforcement. (
) Primary Stakeholders: SB/SE Collection and Chief Counsel. (
) Program Goals: Provide policy and procedural guidance to IRS collection employees working accounts involving deceased taxpayers. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

provides official procedures for employees vestigating and collecting delinquent returns and balances due from a deceased taxpayer’s estate. It provides a roadmap to investigation, and resolution of decedent cases. (
) Congress has delegated to the IRS the responsibility of administering the laws, known as the Internal Revenue Code, found in Title
of the United States Code. Congress enacts these tax laws and the IRS enforces them. (
) The Director, Collection Policy, is responsible for overseeing policy and dures related to collection of decedent tax accounts. (
) Collection and advisory employees authorized to collect tax accounts are sponsible for ensuring procedures are properly followed. (
) Managers are responsible for ensuring that processing, evaluation, and timely actions are taken by employees in accordance with current law, policy and IRM procedures. (
) Per IRM

, Resource Guide for Managers, Collection Group Manager, Territory Manager and Area Director Operational Aid, group managers are charged with ensuring employee case actions are timely and in accordance with current law, policies, and procedures. Group managers are performance evaluations to document how employees are performing their duties and responsibilities to ensure they are working efficiently and to accomplish assigned tasks. (

) Operational and program reviews are conducted to ensure that program delivery and case actions are in accordance with administrative and ance requirements. National quality and consistency reviews are routinely conducted to ensure program consistency and effectiveness in case ing. (
) The Integrated Collection System (ICS) is used to control decedent and document case work. (
) The ENTITY Case Management System can also generate certain unique reports to assist in managing assigned inventory. Internal Revenue Manual
Program Goals: Provide policy and procedural guidance to IRS collection employees working accounts involving deceased taxpayers.
Collection and advisory employees authorized to collect tax accounts are sponsible for ensuring procedures are properly followed.
The ENTITY Case Management System can also generate certain unique reports to assist in managing assigned inventory.
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate

(1) IRM 5.5.1, Decedent and Estate Tax Accounts (2) IRM 5.5.2, Probate Proceedings Resources (3) IRM 5.5.4, Proof of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases (4) Use IRM 5.17.13, Legal Reference Guide, Insolvencies and Decedents’ Estates, and confer with local Counsel and/or Advisory when working decedent cases. Procedures may vary and require local modiﬁcation based on speciﬁc legal requirements for each state. (5) Pub 590-B, Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs) (6) Pub 559, Survivors, Executors and Administrators (1) Remember the following collection guidelines when working an IMF liability that involves a deceased taxpayer. Collection on Decedent If it is a joint liability and Then the secondary taxpayer is pursue collection from the primary deceased taxpayer the primary taxpayer is deceased pursue collection from the secondary taxpayer both taxpayers are deceased follow the guidelines for a single deceased taxpayer (2) Remember the following collecting guidelines when working a BMF liability that involves a deceased taxpayer. If it is a partnership liability Then and all partners are deceased follow the guidelines for a single deceased taxpayer there are one or more surviving pursue collection from surviving partners partners (3) If a joint liability is due and there is a surviving spouse, make a collection de- termination based on the surviving spouse’s assets, as well as the assets in the decedent’s estate. (4) The normal 10-year collection statute applies to collection from the non-
Remember the following collection guidelines when working an IMF liability that involves a deceased taxpayer.
(09-17-2020) General Collection Guidelines on Decedent Accounts

If it is a joint liability and Then the secondary taxpayer is pursue collection from the primary deceased taxpayer the primary taxpayer is deceased pursue collection from the secondary taxpayer both taxpayers are deceased follow the guidelines for a single deceased taxpayer

If it is a partnership liability Then and all partners are deceased follow the guidelines for a single deceased taxpayer there are one or more surviving pursue collection from surviving partners partners
Cases
) For collection of taxes assessed after death, you must look to the ﬁduciary recipients of the decedent’s assets. Give Form

, Notice of Federal Due, and a copy of the NFTL to the party holding the decedent’s assets to notify them of outstanding taxes due. Consult with Advisory regarding the sibility of assessing transferee liability against persons receiving property or asserting personal liability against the ﬁduciary after researching IRM Insolvencies and Decedents’ Estates and IRM
, Fraudulent and Transferee and Other Third Party Liability. (
) For additional information on individuals who may have access to regarding deceased individuals, see IRM
, Deceased Individuals. (
) ACS will secure and document information such as domicile at the date of death and probate court information. Refer to IRM
, Deceased Taxpayers, for speciﬁc research conducted by ACS prior to sending an Actions to the ﬁeld for collection action. (
) ACS will make a lien determination on all decedent accounts in accordance with IRM

, Notice of Federal Tax Lien Determinations and Filing Criteria, lien procedures. Revenue officers working decedent accounts must verify that Notices of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL’s) are recorded in the proper ﬁling location. (
) Per IRM
, Deceased Taxpayer - Balance Due Actions, if the taxpayer owned real property secured by a NFTL at the time of death, ACS update the account to status
for assignment to a revenue officer. The revenue officer will determine the need for any required collection action. (
) If there is an open probate proceeding or assets were distributed prior to standing taxes being paid, ACS will forward a referral to the appropriate Advisory unit. (

) Fact ﬁnding required in a decedent case includes research of probate or surrogate records, as well as internal and third party resources. Proper Actions tion action on a decedent case begins once fact ﬁnding actions are (

) Prior to contact with the ﬁduciary, research all internal resources such as history and IDRS. These sources should provide: • date of death • place of death (including county) • taxpayer’s home address (including county) on the date of death • tax returns that may be due • whether a probate proceeding was or is open, docket number and contact information of ﬁduciary (

) Information Return Program (IRP) can help identify assets owned prior to death and whether those assets have been distributed. IRP should be for the year prior to death, the year of death and the year after death. (
) Research the Automated Lien System (ALS) to determine if a NFTL was recorded. Determine if the NFTL was recorded in the proper ﬁling location, Exhibit
, State and Territory Filing Locations . If not, an NFTL be recorded in the proper ﬁling location where assets are located.
Prior to contact with the ﬁduciary, research all internal resources such as ACS history and IDRS. These sources should provide:

• date of death • place of death (including county) • taxpayer’s home address (including county) on the date of death • tax returns that may be due • whether a probate proceeding was or is open, docket number and contact information of ﬁduciary (

) Information Return Program (IRP) can help identify assets owned prior to death and whether those assets have been distributed. IRP should be checked for the year prior to death, the year of death and the year after death. (
) Research the Automated Lien System (ALS) to determine if a NFTL was recorded. Determine if the NFTL was recorded in the proper ﬁling location, see Exhibit
, State and Territory Filing Locations . If not, an NFTL should be recorded in the proper ﬁling location where assets are located.

5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate Taxes

After you have checked internal sources, make a ﬁeld call to the probate or surrogate’s court or research online if records can be viewed and printed, to determine the type of proceeding that has been ﬁled and to secure copies of pertinent documentation such as:

) After you have checked internal sources, make a ﬁeld call to the probate surrogate’s court or research online if records can be viewed and printed, determine the type of proceeding that has been ﬁled and to secure copies pertinent documentation such as: • death certiﬁcate • will • letters testamentary or other documents identifying the ﬁduciary and ﬁduciary’s contact information • list of assets, such as an inventory and appraisement • proceedings that outline distribution or litigation of the deceased’s assets • list of heirs and their contact information • bonds posted by the ﬁduciary (this may be a levy source) • accountings that indicate liabilities, especially if taxes are listed as a debt of the estate • documents related to a business owned by the decedent (

) Search county courthouse records to: • obtain copies of deeds that show what real property the taxpayer prior to death and how title is currently held in real property • determine whether assets were transferred after death, after assess- ment of taxes or after the NFTL was recorded. (
) Research Accurint to determine if the deceased owned property out of (
) Request input of the TC
on the deceased individual’s SSN for the year death if it is not already input. (
) For guidance on the progression of probate proceedings see IRM
, Probate Proceedings. (

) Opening a probate proceeding may not be required in some states under certain circumstances. For example, where all property of the taxpayer is passed by right of survivorship to the surviving spouse no probate is necessary because the decedent’s interest ceased at death. (
) If no probate ﬁling can be located, assets may be identiﬁed using such as: • IDRS and IRP information • Accurint • Credit bureau reports • County records (
) It may be necessary to contact heirs or third parties familiar with the for information; follow procedures in IRM
, Third Party Contacts . In addition to the sources in IRM
, the following resources may provide contacts: • local obituary of deceased • tax returns may list dependents • state inheritance tax return

letters testamentary or other documents identifying the ﬁduciary and ﬁduciary’s contact information list of assets, such as an inventory and appraisement proceedings that outline distribution or litigation of the deceased’s assets list of heirs and their contact information bonds posted by the ﬁduciary (this may be a levy source) accountings that indicate liabilities, especially if taxes are listed as a debt of the estate
Cases

) Another alternative to a will and probate administration would be the of a trust. A trust involves any arrangement whereby property is transferred from one person to be administered by a trustee for a third party’s beneﬁt beneﬁciary). (
) Assets can be transferred to a trust before or after death. (

) It is necessary to secure a copy of the written trust document to determine: • the type of trust • the trustee of the trust • the beneﬁciaries of the trust • speciﬁc assets to be transferred to the trust • when the assets will be transferred to the trust • ability to modify the trust, terms and conditions • disbursement of the trust assets (

) Some common forms of trusts related to probate are: • Inter Vivos Trust - a trust established during the lifetime of a grantor. avoids probate of the property it holds because the trust entity, not deceased grantor, technically owns the property. Probate is only necessary to move ownership from the name of an individual who is deceased to the living beneﬁciaries • Irrevocable Trust - an inter vivos trust that cannot be altered, modiﬁed or revoked after its creation (absent extenuating circum- stances). Once the grantor transfers property to an irrevocable trust, grantor typically can no longer take the property back from the trust. • Revocable Living Trust or Living Trust - an inter vivos trust that can altered, changed, modiﬁed or revoked. The grantor transfers title to property to a trust and has the power to remove the property from trust, add or delete beneﬁciaries, and buy or sell assets during their lifetime; it becomes irrevocable when the grantor dies. Typically the grantor is the initial trustee as well as the initial beneﬁciary of the and his/her spouse and children are the ultimate beneﬁciaries of the trust. • Living trusts - both revocable and irrevocable - avoid probate of the property they hold because the trust entity and not the decedent cally owns that property. Probate is only necessary to move from the name of an individual who is deceased to the living ries. • Testamentary Trust - a trust that is established under the terms and conditions of a will; the will tells the executor of the estate to create Such trusts take effect after the death of the person making the will. testamentary trust can be changed while the grantor is alive but becomes irrevocable at death when the grantor is unable to change terms of the will. A testamentary trust can’t avoid probate because property to be transferred into it remains in the decedent’s name at time of death - the trust hasn’t been formed and funded yet. Probate necessary to move that property into the name of the trust, just as it would transfer it into the names of living beneﬁciaries. (
) When considering collection against assets in a trust, it is important to determine when the tax lien arose or was recorded in relation to when
common forms of trusts related to probate are:
Inter Vivos Trust

a trust established during the lifetime of a grantor. It avoids probate of the property it holds because the trust entity, not the deceased grantor, technically owns the property. Probate is only necessary to move ownership from the name of an individual who is deceased to the living beneﬁciaries
Irrevocable Trust
an inter vivos trust that cannot be altered, changed, modiﬁed or revoked after its creation (absent extenuating circum
stances). Once the grantor transfers property to an irrevocable trust, grantor typically can no longer take the property back from the trust.
Revocable Living Trust or Living Trust

an inter vivos trust that can be altered, changed, modiﬁed or revoked. The grantor transfers title to property to a trust and has the power to remove the property from the trust, add or delete beneﬁciaries, and buy or sell assets during their lifetime; it becomes irrevocable when the grantor dies. Typically the grantor is the initial trustee as well as the initial beneﬁciary of the trust, and his/her spouse and children are the ultimate beneﬁciaries of the trust.
Living trusts
both revocable and irrevocable

avoid probate of the property they hold because the trust entity and not the decedent cally owns that property. Probate is only necessary to move ownership from the name of an individual who is deceased to the living beneﬁcia
ries.
Testamentary Trust

a trust that is established under the terms and conditions of a will; the will tells the executor of the estate to create it. Such trusts take effect after the death of the person making the will. A testamentary trust can be changed while the grantor is alive but becomes irrevocable at death when the grantor is unable to change terms of the will. A testamentary trust can’t avoid probate because the property to be transferred into it remains in the decedent’s name at time of death
the trust hasn’t been formed and funded yet. Probate is necessary to move that property into the name of the trust, just as it would transfer it into the names of living beneﬁciaries.

When considering collection against assets in a trust, it is important to determine when the tax lien arose or was recorded in relation to when
Decedent Estates and Estate were transferred to the trust. See IRM
, Trusts and Beneﬁcial Interests, for information on lien attachment and IRM
, Trusts, for guidance on levy of trust assets . (
) Local Counsel should be consulted to review terms/conditions of the trust and the impact of the tax lien before pursuing collection against assets in a trust. (
) Once you complete the fact-ﬁnding phase, contact the ﬁduciary and make demand for any tax due or outstanding returns. Follow requirements in IRM
, Effective Initial Contact. Give Form
, Notice of Federal Taxes Due, and a copy of the NFTL to the ﬁduciary. Form

warns the ﬁduciary of personal liability if lower priority claims are paid ahead of the Service’s claim. Advise the ﬁduciary that penalties and interest continue to accrue until the balance is paid in full. (
) See IRM

, Fiduciary Authority, for guidance on how to identify the ﬁduciary. If there is no executor, ﬁduciary or administrator appointed, then any person in actual or constructive possession of any property of the decedent may be considered a statutory executor and may be liable to pay taxes or have personal liability. An executor is deﬁned in Treas. Reg. §

) Collection against assets not controlled by the court is not restricted. Recording a NFTL or other collection action may continue. Make every effort work with ﬁduciaries to secure payment or returns prior to enforcement. Consult with Counsel or Advisory before levy or seizure of probate assets, or you are unsure whether or not assets are under court control. (
) Ensure that information provided by a ﬁduciary or beneﬁciary regarding and debts is corroborated by your own investigation. (

) If the ﬁduciary does not provide the asset information requested or has not submitted required documents with the probate court, such as an accounting estate assets, a summons can be issued to the ﬁduciary. The IRS should not have to request a state court judge to issue an order for the ﬁduciary to do what he already had a duty to perform -- ﬁle an accounting of assets. If the ﬁduciary chooses to ignore the summons, IRS can seek enforcement in the federal courts instead of waiting for a state court to act. (

) Ideally, research is conducted before interviewing a ﬁduciary or third party about the current status of assets. Useful questions during the fact ﬁnding phase include: • Is the probate proceeding open? • Is there a listing of probate assets? • Did the taxpayer own assets out of state? • Did the taxpayer have assets in a trust? • Did the taxpayer own publicly traded stock or stock in a closely held corporation? • Are there any exempt, abandoned or after acquired assets? • Were the probate assets distributed? • Did the taxpayer have retirement accounts? IRAs? • Who received assets and when? Ask for a description of the assets the names, addresses and contact information of those who received assets. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Local Counsel should be consulted to review terms/conditions of the trust and the impact of the tax lien before pursuing collection against assets in a trust.

If the ﬁduciary does not provide the asset information requested or has not submitted required documents with the probate court, such as an accounting of estate assets, a summons can be issued to the ﬁduciary. The IRS should not have to request a state court judge to issue an order for the ﬁduciary to do what he already had a duty to perform
ﬁle an accounting of assets. If the ﬁduciary chooses to ignore the summons, IRS can seek enforcement in the federal courts instead of waiting for a state court to act.
5.5.3.5.1 (09-17-2020) Probing Questions

Is the probate proceeding open? Is there a listing of probate assets? Did the taxpayer own assets out of state? Did the taxpayer have assets in a trust? Did the taxpayer own publicly traded stock or stock in a closely held corporation? Are there any exempt, abandoned or after acquired assets? Were the probate assets distributed? Did the taxpayer have retirement accounts? IRAs? Who received assets and when? Ask for a description of the assets the names, addresses and contact information of those who received assets.
Cases

page • Did the deceased own a business? If yes, what is the EIN? Who is currently operating the business? • What is the type of business entity (sole proprietorship, partnership)? Are there business assets? • Is a ﬁnancial statement available for the business? • Is the business in compliance with ﬁling and paying requirements? • Is there current litigation pending that affects probate assets? (

) Determine whether the NFTL was recorded, when it was recorded in relation the date of death and whether it was recorded in the appropriate ﬁling that coincides with property owned by the decedent. (
) If there is an error with the styling of the NFTL or the location in which the NFTL was recorded, take action to either ﬁle a new NFTL or amend the recorded NFTL. See IRM
, NFTL Corrections, for guidance on ing lien errors. (

) It is important to determine what property the lien attaches to and the ment’s position among other creditors. Then the assessment lien If assessment is made: attaches to: before death property owned by the taxpayer and follows property into probate or to the transferee. after death any probate property in the tax- payer’s estate at the time of assessment. (

) If the NFTL is recorded on an assessment made before death, it attaches assets owned by the taxpayer and follows those assets into the estate or the hands of the transferee. The Service’s priority position with respect to those assets, is determined based on the date of the ﬁling of the NFTL before the taxpayer’s death. It is important to determine during your research what the taxpayer owned before death and how they were titled, when the lien recorded. Consult with Advisory or Area Counsel concerning levy or seizure these assets. (

) If the NFTL is recorded on a post-death assessment, it would not reach property that passed to heirs automatically at the time of death (non-probate property), but it would reach any probate property in the taxpayer’s “estate” the time of the assessment. Title to the decedent’s property passes to the estate or heirs upon death. It is important to determine during your research what assets were in the taxpayer’s “estate” when the lien was recorded. (
) The assessment lien under section

attaches to all of decedent’s and rights and survives on property passing to the estate or passing by operation of law to others. For issues related to property held with rights of survivorship or in a tenancy by the entirety, consult Area Counsel. A NFTL not be required to initiate levy or seizure. The assessment lien alone is suffi- cient where competing claimants are not protected under IRC
(a). Internal Revenue Manual

Title to the decedent’s property passes to the estate or heirs upon death. It is important to determine during your research what assets were in the taxpayer’s “estate” when the lien was recorded. (

If the NFTL is recorded on an assessment made before death, it attaches to assets owned by the taxpayer and follows those assets into the estate or the hands of the transferee. The Service’s priority position with respect to those assets, is determined based on the date of the ﬁling of the NFTL before the taxpayer’s death. It is important to determine during your research what assets the taxpayer owned before death and how they were titled, when the lien was recorded. Consult with Advisory or Area Counsel concerning levy or seizure of these assets.
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate

The federal tax lien remains on property that passes by a beneﬁciary deed (which is created by state statute). The beneﬁciary here does not hold in common ownership with the decedent with rights of survivorship. Before death, the decedent has the right to revoke or change the beneﬁciary deed and the beneﬁciary does not have rights to the property before the taxpayer’s death. Consult with Area Counsel concerning levy or seizure of these assets.
If a decedent account is under Advisory control, Advisory is responsible for ﬁling, amending and re-ﬁling NFTL’s as necessary.

Notices of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL’s) and notices such as ﬁnal demand letters or CDP notice, should be styled and sent as indicated in the table below. In this example, John Smith is the decedent, Jane Smith is his surviving spouse, and Robert Drew is the executor, where applicable.
(03-26-2010) Styling and Mailing of Notices

IF the liability is... Then styling should include... a joint assessment, Name: John Smith (Deceased) and Jane Smith • Address: Jane Smith’s address • Notices must be sent sepa- rately to the last known addresses of both spouses. an individual assessment, and a Name: John Smith (Deceased) ﬁduciary has been appointed, • Address: John Smith’s last known address • Send notices to the ﬁduciary, Robert Drew, at his address. an individual assessment, and no Name: John Smith (Deceased) ﬁduciary has been appointed, • Address: John Smith’s last known address • Send notices to John Smith’s last known address based on Form 1041, Name: Estate of John Smith • Address: John Smith’s last known address • Send notices to the ﬁduciary, Robert Drew, at his address.
The NFTL must identify the taxpayer, the party against whom the was made. The ﬁduciary or his address should not be added to the NFTL.

Notices must be mailed to the ﬁduciary. If no ﬁduciary is appointed, notices should be mailed to the decedent’s last known address. The ﬁduciary for the decedent has the authority to exercise CDP rights on the behalf of decedent.
Cases
) Generally, the Service should not levy on property in control of the probate court. Consult local Area Counsel regarding the effect of probate and local regarding property interests. (
) Revenue officers can levy on any property subject to the assessment lien or property of the taxpayer’s estate. (

) If the ﬁduciary has control of estate assets, a levy can be served on the ﬁduciary. If there is a levy source that has some sort of income due to the estate (e.g., rental or interest income), you may levy that source directly. If estate generates income that becomes property of the estate, it can be reached by levy. (
) If a notice of levy will be issued Letter
must be sent to the ﬁduciary, if Letter
was not previously issued to the taxpayer. (

) Inherited IRAs are not retirements funds, and thus, can be treated differently from non-inherited IRAs. Levying on retirement assets, including IRAs, has IRA different, more restrictive standards than levying on other types of property. (

) There are three factors listed below that differentiate an inherited IRA from a participant-owned IRA. These factors characterize an inherited IRA as that was set aside for the original owner’s retirement and not for the desig- nated beneﬁciary’s retirement. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA cannot make additional to the account, while an IRA owner can. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA must take required minimum butions from the account regardless of how far away the beneﬁciary from actually retiring. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA can withdraw all of the funds at time and for any purpose without a penalty, while an IRA owner must generally wait until age
to take penalty-free distributions. (
) IRC

)(C)(ii) treats an IRA as inherited if: • the individual for whose beneﬁt the account or annuity is maintained acquired such account by reason of the death of another individual, • such individual was not the surviving spouse of such other individual. (
) If the inherited traditional IRA is from anyone other than a deceased the beneﬁciary cannot treat it as his or her own IRA, the IRA will be treated an inherited IRA. (

) Review of IRPTR may lead to inherited IRAs that have passed or will pass beneﬁciary subject to a ﬁled lien or assessment lien. IRP should be checked for the year prior to death, the year of death and the year after death to see the deceased owned an IRA. It is possible that the IRA will pass to a desig- nated beneﬁciary and not be reﬂected on the probate inventory. (
) If a distribution is made to a beneﬁciary, trust, or estate, Form

-R, bution From Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Proﬁt-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contracts, etc. is prepared using the name and TIN of the beneﬁ- ciary, trust, or estate, not that of the decedent. If there are multiple beneﬁciaries, each are reported on Form
-R for only the amount paid the beneﬁciary whose name appears on the Form
-R, and the (

If there is a levy source that has some sort of income due to the estate (e.g., rental or interest income), you may levy that source directly. If estate generates income that becomes property of the estate, it can be reached by levy. (

These factors characterize an inherited IRA as that was set aside for the original owner’s retirement and not for the desig- nated beneﬁciary’s retirement. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA cannot make additional to the account, while an IRA owner can.

participant-owned IRA. These factors characterize an inherited IRA as that was set aside for the original owner’s retirement and not for the desig- nated beneﬁciary’s retirement. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA cannot make additional to the account, while an IRA owner can. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA must take required minimum butions from the account regardless of how far away the beneﬁciary from actually retiring. • The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA can withdraw all of the funds at time and for any purpose without a penalty, while an IRA owner must generally wait until age
to take penalty-free distributions. IRC

)(C)(ii) treats an IRA as inherited if: • the individual for whose beneﬁt the account or annuity is maintained acquired such account by reason of the death of another individual, • such individual was not the surviving spouse of such other individual. If the inherited traditional IRA is from anyone other than a deceased spouse the beneﬁciary cannot treat it as his or her own IRA, the IRA will be treated an inherited IRA. Review of IRPTR may lead to inherited IRAs that have passed or will pass beneﬁciary subject to a ﬁled lien or assessment lien. IRP should be checked for the year prior to death, the year of death and the year after death to see the deceased owned an IRA. It is possible that the IRA will pass to a desig- nated beneﬁciary and not be reﬂected on the probate inventory. If a distribution is made to a beneﬁciary, trust, or estate, Form

-R, bution From Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Proﬁt-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contracts, etc. is prepared using the name and TIN of the beneﬁ- ciary, trust, or estate, not that of the decedent. If there are multiple beneﬁciaries, each are reported on Form
-R for only the amount paid to the beneﬁciary whose name appears on the Form
-R, and the

The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA cannot make additional contributions to the account, while an IRA owner can. The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA must take required minimum distri- butions from the account regardless of how far away the beneﬁciary is from actually retiring. The beneﬁciary of an inherited IRA can withdraw all of the funds at any time and for any purpose without a penalty, while an IRA owner must generally wait until age
to take penalty-free distributions.

Review of IRPTR may lead to inherited IRAs that have passed or will pass to beneﬁciary subject to a ﬁled lien or assessment lien. IRP should be checked for the year prior to death, the year of death and the year after death to see if the deceased owned an IRA. It is possible that the IRA will pass to a desig- nated beneﬁciary and not be reﬂected on the probate inventory.

is used regardless of the age of the participant to indicate payment to a decedent’s beneﬁciary, including an estate or trust. which IRA issuers/ trustees are required to ﬁle. In the year in which an IRA holder dies, the IRA trustee must submit at least two Forms

: • one reporting the fair market value of the IRA with respect to the decedent (including any contributions made by the decedent in the of death), • and another reporting the value of the IRA with respect to each beneﬁ- ciary. • For each subsequent year, Form

) Inherited IRAs are subject to the normal levy procedures as ordinary property without the usual considerations regarding levies on IRAs. They are not subject to the special levy procedures because they are not retirement funds. See IRM
), Delegation Order
, Levy on Property in the Hands of a Third Party, for levy authority. (

) If collection action is being pursued against estate assets of the deceased taxpayer in the hands of beneﬁciaries, the beneﬁciaries do not have CDP since they are not the ″taxpayer″. The beneﬁciary is holding an estate asset that the assessment tax lien attached. Collection is being pursued against the estate asset to satisfy the decedent’s tax liability. In these circumstances, do not issue the Letter
to the beneﬁciary or holder of estate assets. (

) However, although not entitled to CDP rights, such party may be entitled to collection appeal program (CAP) rights. For example, CAP is available where party asserts an interest superior to the Service in the levied funds and the Service has denied a request to release the levy or to return the funds. (
) In lieu of the Letter
, give Form
, Notice of Federal Taxes Due, a copy of the NFTL to the executor, estate administrator or beneﬁciary the decedent’s assets to notify them outstanding taxes have not been paid. The Form

puts recipients of estate assets on notice that assets they received before taxes were paid are subject to levy to pay the unpaid taxes. This form has no CDP or appeal rights; it is a notice of tax due. (
) You must mail notices to the executor. If no executor is appointed, mail to the decedent’s last known address. The executor has the authority to exercise CAP rights on the behalf of the estate.

) When levying on an inherited IRA document the ICS history that the beneﬁ- ciary received the inherited IRA from your deceased taxpayer and that the is subject to levy since it is not retirement funds. Secure concurrence in the ICS history from the Group Manager that the case was reviewed and agrees the levy is being issued on an inherited IRA. (
) Use Form

-A, Notice of Levy, under the section “Special instructions for certain property levied” state “This Notice of Levy attaches to an inherited that is subject to levy, thus not considered to be retirement funds. You are hereby notiﬁed that the property and rights to property described below are subject to tax lien provided by IRC

of the Internal Revenue Code for unpaid income taxes owed by the [Name of Decedent], using the Decedent’s Tax Identiﬁcation Number [Decedent’s TIN]. Said property and rights to property are hereby levied upon and seized for satisfaction of the aforesaid tax, together with all additions as provided by law. Demand is hereby made upon you to turn over said property and rights to property, or if less, the full amount of the unpaid tax liability speciﬁed above.” (

) Circumstances where the holder of the inherited IRA takes a distribution to which the FTL has attached and uses it to fund the purchase of other assets, such as the purchase of a house or car, present issues not unique to IRAs. In that situation, the Service may be able to assert that the now tuted property, i.e., the house, car, etc., is encumbered by the tax lien. In to do so, the Service will need to address issues of commingled funds and tracing the encumbered distribution to the purportedly substituted property. In addition, if the tax lien attaches to the substituted property, there may be priority issues if encumbered. (

) Seek advice from Advisory or Counsel concerning other federal and state remedies that may be available to force the ﬁduciary or beneﬁciaries to pay decedent’s income or business tax debt. In that situation, the Service may be able to assert that the now substi- tuted property, i.e., the house, car, etc., is encumbered by the tax lien. ) Seek advice from Advisory or Counsel concerning other federal and state remedies that may be available to force the ﬁduciary or beneﬁciaries to pay or Transferee decedent’s income or business tax debt. (09-17-2020) Fiduciary or Transferee Liability

A ﬁduciary is a person entrusted with the property of another. It is the responsi- bility of a legally appointed or designated ﬁduciary to control, maintain, and distribute that property in a manner deﬁned by law. The general rule is that in a case involving a decedent the ﬁduciary must pay the federal tax claim before other claims. A ﬁduciary who fails to pay federal tax claims may be held per- sonally liable under 31 U.S.C. Section 3713.

or recorded NFTL. determine who received assets and the value of these assets.
